habitat_description:
Great Plains/Southwest:
Prior to 1987, this species was considered a subspecies of G. bursarius. The two are essentially reproductively isolated with only a small area of range overlap in which hybrid offspring are sterile (Schimdly 2004). Habitat requirements are equivalent to those of G. bursarius. It is considered a vulnerable species because of the small range of required sandy soils habitat in western Texas and southeastern New Mexico (NatureServe). This fossorial rodent is restricted to areas with deep, sandy, aeolian soils; usually in native yucca-grassland habitat, although it is also found on grassy roadsides, pastures, and lawns (Bradley and Baker, in Wilson and Ruff 1999)(quoted directly from NatureServe).
